tit.e: Netsuke (miniature carving attached to the end of a cord hanging from a pouch)
tit.cmt: (miniature carving attached to the end of a cord hanging from a pouch) を追記しました。
tit.e: Netsuke (miniature carving attached to the end of a cord hanging from a pouch)

sen.j: 根付（ねつけ、ねづけ）とは、江戸時代に煙草入れ、矢立、印籠、小型の革製鞄（お金、食べ物、筆記用具、薬、煙草など小間物を入れた）などを紐で帯から吊るし持ち歩くときに用いた留め具。
sen.e: Netsuke (also called nezuke) is an attachment suspended by string from the obi (kimono sash), in which can be carried things like tobacco pouches, yatate (brush holder), inro (a tiny box which contains medicine or one's seal and a small red ink pad) and leather bags (pouches for accessories including money, foods, writing utensils, medicines and tobaccos).

Netsuke (also called "nezuke") is an attachment used in the Edo period when people carried tobacco pouches, yatate (brush holder), inro (a tiny box which contains medicine or one's seal and a small red ink pad) and leather bags (pouches for accessories including money, foods, writing utensils, medicines and tobaccos) by suspending from the obi sash by a cord.

Netsuke (also called "nezuke") is an attachment used in the Edo period when people carried tobacco pouches, yatate (brush holder), inro (a tiny box which contains medicine or one's seal and a small red ink pad) and leather bags (pouches for accessories including money, foods, writing utensils, medicines and tobaccos) by suspending from the obi sash by a cord.

sen.j: 江戸時代から近代にかけての古根付と、昭和、平成の現代根付に大別される。
sen.e: There are two main types of netsuke: historical netsuke made from the Edo Period to the modern era and contemporary netsuke made from the Showa Period to the Heisei Period.
There are two main types of netsuke: historical netsuke made from the Edo Period to the modern era and contemporary netsuke made from the Showa Period to the Heisei Period.
There are two main types of netsuke: historical netsuke made from the Edo Period to the modern era and contemporary netsuke made from the Showa Period to the Heisei Period.

sen.j: 高円宮憲仁親王が、収集家として名高かったことでも知られる。
sen.e: Netsuke is also famous for the fact that Imperial Prince Takamadonomiya Norihito was a collector of them.
Netsuke is also famous for the fact that Imperial Prince Takamadonomiya Norihito was a renowned collector of it.
sen.cmt: a collector に renowned を追記しました。文末の them を it に修正しました。
sen.e: Netsuke is also famous for the fact that Imperial Prince Takamadonomiya Norihito was a renowned collector of it.

sen.j: 製作国の日本以上に、日本国外では骨董品的収集品として高く評価されている。
sen.e: They are valued highly as antiques less so in Japan (the country of production) than outside.
It is valued higher in abroad as the antique rather than in its manufacturing country, Japan.
It is valued higher in abroad as the antique rather than in its manufacturing country, Japan.

sen.j: ポケットの無い男性用の和服で袋や印籠等を持ち歩く場合に、袋や印籠などに付けられた紐の他方の端に取付け、紐を帯の下に挟み、根付を帯の上方に出す事によって引っ掛って袋や印籠などが落ちないようにする目的で用いられた。
sen.e: Used to carry round things including pouches and inro when wearing pocketless men's kimono, netsuke helped prevent such items from falling: string attached to the pouches or inro was pulled under and over the the obi, and then the other end would be tied to the netsuke, which was too large to fall through the obi.

Used to carry round things including pouches and inro when wearing pocketless men's kimono, netsuke helped prevent such items from falling: string attached to the pouches or inro was pulled under and over the the obi, and then the other end would be tied to the netsuke, which was too large to fall through the obi.

Used to carry round things including pouches and inro when wearing pocketless men's kimono, netsuke helped prevent such items from falling: string attached to the pouches or inro was pulled under and over the the obi, and then the other end would be tied to the netsuke, which was too large to fall through the obi.

sen.j: 大きさは数cmから、小さいものは1cm位のものもある。
sen.e: The size varies from one centimeter to a few centimeters.
The size varies from one centimeter to several centimeters.
sen.cmt: a few を several に修正しました。
sen.e: The size varies from one centimeter to several centimeters.

sen.j: 材質は堅い木（ツゲ、イチイ、黒檀等）や象牙などが多い。
sen.e: The material is usually hard woods (such as box, yew, and ebony) and ivory.
The material is usually hard woods (such as box, yew, and ebony) and ivory.
The material is usually hard woods (such as box, yew, and ebony) and ivory.

sen.j: 江戸初期のものは簡素なものが多いが、時代と共に実用性と共に装飾性も重視されるようになり、江戸時代中期に入って爆発的に流行した。
sen.e: Although netsuke in the early Edo Period was usually simple, not only its practical utility but also its ornamentation became more highly valued over time, and it became very popular in the middle of the Edo Period.

Although netsuke in the early Edo period was usually simple, not only its practical utility but also its ornamentation became more highly valued over time, and it became explosively popular in the mid-Edo period.
sen.cmt: Period を period に修正しました。very popular in the middle of the を explosively popular in the mid- に修正しました。
sen.e: Although netsuke in the early Edo period was usually simple, not only its practical utility but also its ornamentation became more highly valued over time, and it became explosively popular in the mid-Edo period.

sen.j: この頃になると細かい彫刻が施されるようになり、根付自体が美術品として収集の対象となった。
sen.e: Around that time, detailed carvings came to be made on them, and netsuke began to be targeted as collectable art objects.
Around that time, netsuke got to be carved finely and netsuke itself became the target of collectable art objects.
sen.cmt: detailed carvings 以降全文修正しました。
sen.e: Around that time, netsuke got to be carved finely and netsuke itself became the target of collectable art objects.

sen.j: 明治に入ると海外から高い評価を得て主に輸出用に生産されるようになるが、この頃になると実用性を失い穴の空いた小型の精緻な彫刻となってしまう。
sen.e: However, after the Meiji Period netsuke became highly valued abroad and began to be produced mainly for export, losing its original function and coming to be no more than a pierced small elaborate carving.

However, after the Meiji period netsuke became highly valued abroad and began to be produced mainly for export, losing its original function and coming to be no more than a pierced small elaborate carving.
sen.cmt: Period を period に修正しました。
sen.e: However, after the Meiji period netsuke became highly valued abroad and began to be produced mainly for export, losing its original function and coming to be no more than a pierced small elaborate carving.

sen.j: 大正、昭和を経て一時衰退に向かうが、平成に入って様々な分野から技術者・多種多様な素材が参入、現代根付として再び動きが活発になりつつある。
sen.e: The popularity of netsuke temporarily declined after the Taisho and Showa Periods, but technical experts from various fields, working with a wide variety of materials, entered the netsuke market in the Heisei Period and a contemporary netsuke movement emerged.

The popularity of netsuke temporarily declined after the Taisho and Showa periods, but technical experts from various fields, working with a wide variety of materials, entered the netsuke market in the Heisei period and a contemporary netsuke movement emerged.
sen.cmt: Period, Periods を それぞれ period, periods に修正しました。
sen.e: The popularity of netsuke temporarily declined after the Taisho and Showa periods, but technical experts from various fields, working with a wide variety of materials, entered the netsuke market in the Heisei period and a contemporary netsuke movement emerged.

sen.j: 室町時代が終わり、徳川家康の天下が始まるのに合わせて、家康はある事を直参旗本や外様大名に奨励した。
sen.e: In time for the end of the Muromachi Period and the start of the reign of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, Ieyasu recommended one thing in particular to Jikisan-hatamoto (warriors serves directly to Shogun) and Tozama daimyo (nonhereditary feudal lords in Japan during the Edo Period).
sen.cmt: 「直参旗本」の英訳：下記参照http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110004644734/en「外様大名」の英訳：下記参照http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/601363/tozama-daimyo
sen.e: In time for the end of the Muromachi period and the start of the reign of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, Ieyasu recommended one thing in particular to Jikisan-hatamoto (warriors serves directly to Shogun) and Tozama daimyo (nonhereditary feudal lords).
sen.cmt: Period を period に修正しました。in Japan during the Edo Period を削除しました。
sen.e: In time for the end of the Muromachi period and the start of the reign of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, Ieyasu recommended one thing in particular to Jikisan-hatamoto (warriors serves directly to Shogun) and Tozama daimyo (nonhereditary feudal lords).

sen.j: それは、太平の世になっても、外出時に常備薬（切り傷・腹痛・頭痛薬等）を持ち歩くことであった。
sen.e: This was, even in peacetime, to carry round basic medicines (for cuts, stomachache, headache, etc) whenever leaving home.
It was, even in peacetime, to carry basic medicines (for cuts, stomachache, headache, etc) when going out.
sen.cmt: This を It に修正しました。round を削除しました。whenever leaving home を when going out に修正しました。
sen.e: It was, even in peacetime, to carry basic medicines (for cuts, stomachache, headache, etc) when going out.

sen.j: 当時、家康は相当な薬愛用家であり、自分のみならず、高級武士や公家等にその大切さを説いた。
sen.e: At that time, Ieyasu was a regular user of medicines, and he pointed out their importance not only for himself but also for higher-ranking samurai, and court nobles, etc.
At that time, Ieyasu was a frequent taker of medication, and he pointed out their importance not only for himself but also for higher-ranking samurai, and court nobles, etc.
sen.cmt: a regular user of medicines を a frequent taker of medication に修正しました。
sen.e: At that time, Ieyasu was a frequent taker of medication, and he pointed out their importance not only for himself but also for higher-ranking samurai, and court nobles, etc.

sen.j: しかし、彼らは常備薬を携帯するに当たって、その入れ物をどうするか、思案に困った。
sen.e: However, they were at a loss for how to carry the medicine containers.
sen.cmt: 原文：「思案に困った」→「思案した」または「思案に暮れた」だと思います。
sen.e: However, they were at a loss for the container to carry their medicines.
sen.cmt: at a loss for 以下を全文修正しました。
sen.e: However, they were at a loss for the container to carry their medicines.

sen.j: そこで当時彼らは自宅にあった印籠（印鑑と朱肉を入れた小さな引き出し小箱）に目をつけた。
sen.e: They decided upon an inro (a small box with a drawer contained their own seal and a vermilion inkpad) which they had at their house at that time.
They had an eye on an inro (a small box with a drawer contained their own seal and a vermilion inkpad) which they had in their house at that time.
sen.cmt: decided upon を had an eye on に修正しました。at their house を in their house に修正しました。
sen.e: They had an eye on an inro (a small box with a drawer contained their own seal and a vermilion inkpad) which they had in their house at that time.

sen.j: その自宅用印籠をさらに小型化し、印鑑や朱肉の代わりに薬を入れ、携帯用薬籠としたのである。
sen.e: They created smaller versions of the inro that they were already using at home, and put medicines in place of the seal and vermillion inkpad so that the new inro could be used as a portable medicine container.
They made their inro at home smaller, put their medicines instead of their seals and vermilion inkpad, and used it as their portable pill case.
They made their inro at home smaller, put their medicines instead of their seals and vermilion inkpad, and used it as their portable pill case.

sen.j: しかし、名称は“印籠”を使い続けた。
sen.e: They continued, however, to use its original name "inro."
They continued, however, to use its original name "inro."
They continued, however, to use its original name "inro."

sen.j: 薬缶を薬煎じの目的以外で、単に湯を沸かす容器の名称に使い続けても、名称は“薬缶”のままである現象と同じことが起こったのである。
sen.e: The same thing happened to "yakan": yakan was a kettle originally used for making medicines, the name coming from the Chinese character 薬缶 whose literal meaning is 'medicine can.'
The same phenomenon happened with "yakan,"(kettle) in Chinese character 薬缶 which literally means 'medicine can,' was used not only decocting medicines but also just boiling water.

The same phenomenon happened with "yakan,"(kettle) or 薬缶 in Chinese characters; it literally means 'medicine can' and was originally used for decocting medicines; however it was used for boiling water as well and people continued to use the original name "yakan" for it.

sen.j: この印籠を武士やその奥方が使用する場合、帯からぶら提げる時に、「留め具」の役目を果たしたのが「根付」である。
sen.e: When Samurai and their wives used these inro and hung them from their kimono sashes, it was a 'netsuke' that functioned as a 'catch'.
When Samurai and their wives used these inro and hung them from their kimono sashes, it was a 'netsuke' that functioned as a 'catch'.
When Samurai and their wives used these inro and hung them from their kimono sashes, it was a 'netsuke' that functioned as a 'catch'.

sen.j: 印籠の普及期である江戸時代初期には、この根付として、銅製の糸印（いといん）が多く使用されたと言われている。
sen.e: In the early Edo Period when inro became widespread, as netsuke, apparently itoin (copper seals imported from China around the 16th century) were commonly used.
In the early Edo period when inro became widespread, as netsuke, apparently itoin (copper seals imported from China around the 16th century) were often used.
sen.cmt: Period を period に修正しました。Commonly を often に修正しました。
sen.e: In the early Edo period when inro became widespread, as netsuke, apparently itoin (copper seals imported from China around the 16th century) were often used.

sen.j: この「糸印」とは、室町時代中期から後期にかけて、中国からの貿易船により運ばれた絹糸の受領印として、絹糸と共に荷受主に渡され、荷受主発行の受領書に受領印として押されたものである。
sen.e: This 'itoin' was, from the middle to the end of the Muromachi Period, used as a receipt stamp for silken threads imported by trading ships from China, to be issued by the consignee.

'Itoin' was a receipt stamp for silken threads imported by trading ships from China, which was handed with the threads to consignee and stamped on the receipt issued by the consignee from the middle to the end of the Muromachi period.

'Itoin' was a receipt stamp for silken threads imported by trading ships from China, which was handed with the threads to consignee and stamped on the receipt issued by the consignee from the middle to the end of the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 一取引一回のみの役目で、毎回異なった手彫り又は、鋳造文字が使われ、荷渡しの安全に役立ったのである。
sen.e: Used just once per transaction, with different hand-carved or cast characters used each time, itoin helped to make deliveries safer.
Used only once per transaction with different hand-carved or cast characters each time, itoin made deliveries safer.
Used only once per transaction with different hand-carved or cast characters each time, itoin made deliveries safer.

sen.j: 使用後は、荷受主に寄贈され、二度と受領印として使用されることはなかった。
sen.e: After use, it was given to consignee and never used as a receipt stamp again.
It was given to the consignee after use and never used as a receipt stamp again.
sen.cmt: After use, it was given to consignee の語順を入れ替えました。
sen.e: It was given to the consignee after use and never used as a receipt stamp again.

sen.j: 室町後期において、日本国内には相当数の使用済み「糸印」が存在していた。
sen.e: At the end of the Muromachi Period, there were a considerable number of used 'itoin' in Japan.
At the end of the Muromachi period, there were a considerable number of used 'itoin' in Japan.
sen.cmt: Period を period に修正しました。
sen.e: At the end of the Muromachi period, there were a considerable number of used 'itoin' in Japan.

sen.j: 当時この「糸印」の著名蒐集家が、豊臣秀吉であった。
sen.e: At that time, a famous collector of these 'itoin' was Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
At that time, a famous collector of these 'itoin' was Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
At that time, a famous collector of these 'itoin' was Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 高級武士もそれに倣い、「糸印」の蒐集に励み、各屋敷には少なからずの「糸印」が存在し、極自然的に印籠を提げる役割を果たした。
sen.e: Following his lead, higher-ranking samurai competed to collect 'itoin' and because there were quite a few 'itoin' in their homes these were used to hang inro from their obi.

Following his lead, higher-ranking samurai competed to collect 'itoin'; and because there were quite a few 'itoin' in their residences, their itoin naturally played a role to hang inro from their obi.
sen.cmt: and because 以下を全文修正しました。
sen.e: Following his lead, higher-ranking samurai competed to collect 'itoin'; and because there were quite a few 'itoin' in their residences, their itoin naturally played a role to hang inro from their obi.

sen.j: しかしこの「糸印」は角張った形をしていた為に、帯を傷めてしまう傾向があり、現在の様な“なごみ感”がある手触り仕上げになったのは、17世紀に成ってからである。
sen.e: However, these 'itoin' tended to damage obi because of their angular shape, and from the 17th century they were polished to the smooth comfortable texture associated with the contemporary style.
However, these 'itoin' tended to damage obi because of their angular shape, and from the 17th century they were polished to the smooth comfortable texture associated with the contemporary style.
However, these 'itoin' tended to damage obi because of their angular shape, and from the 17th century they were polished to the smooth comfortable texture associated with the contemporary style.

sen.j: また、17～18世紀にかけて、“なごみ感”プラス“洒落”・“エスプリ”・“伊達心”等が付け加えられ、近代の進化した根付が完成されたのである。
sen.e: Also, from 17th and 18th centuries, a range of new designs - comfortable or funny, witty or elegant - contributed to the making of the modern netsuke.
Also, from 17th and 18th centuries, a range of new designs - comfortable or funny, witty or elegant - contributed to the completion of the modern and advanced netsuke.
sen.cmt: the making of the modern netsuke をthe completion of the modern and advanced netsuke に修正しました。
sen.e: Also, from 17th and 18th centuries, a range of new designs - comfortable or funny, witty or elegant - contributed to the completion of the modern and advanced netsuke.

sen.j: その要因として、17世紀頃までに「印籠」・「根付」のセット普及が、高級武士・公家から茶道・商人・町人までに及び、その粋なファッション表現が昇華されたから、と考えられる。
sen.e: It is thought that the reason for this was that by the 17th century sets of 'inro' and 'netsuke' had spread not only amongst higher-ranking samurai and court nobles but also amongst people involved in tea ceremony culture, as well as merchants and townspeople, as an expression of style.

The reason is considered that by the 17th century sets of 'inro' and 'netsuke' had spread not only among higher-ranking samurai and court nobles but also among people involved in tea ceremony culture, as well as merchants and townspeople, as an expression of style.
sen.cmt: It is thought that the reason for this was をThe reason is considered に修正しました。amongst を among に修正しました。
sen.e: The reason is considered that by the 17th century sets of 'inro' and 'netsuke' had spread not only among higher-ranking samurai and court nobles but also among people involved in tea ceremony culture, as well as merchants and townspeople, as an expression of style.

sen.j: また、富裕層が所持した印籠や根付には、蒔絵や象牙等が使用され、彼らはお金に糸目をつけない芸術性を求めた。
sen.e: Inro and netsuke for the wealthy classes came to be lacquered, with ivory, since these classes were interested in aesthetics without regard to cost.
Inro and netsuke for the wealthy classes came to be lacquered, with ivory, since these classes were interested in aesthetics without regard to cost.
Inro and netsuke for the wealthy classes came to be lacquered, with ivory, since these classes were interested in aesthetics without regard to cost.

sen.j: 当時の“日本人の心意気”を今に伝えるのが「根付」である。
sen.e: The one thing that communicates "the spirit of true-born Japanese at that time" down to today is 'netsuke.'
It is 'netsuke' which has handed down the "spirit of true-born Japanese" at that time till now.
It is 'netsuke' which has handed down the "spirit of true-born Japanese" at that time till now.

sen.j: 現在、世界中の多くの人々から「根付」の持つ高い芸術性は、日本独特の精緻的文化として認められている。
sen.e: The high aesthetics of 'netsuke' are now accepted by many people around the world as an example of sophisticated and unique Japanese culture..
The high aesthetics of 'netsuke' are now accepted by many people around the world as an example of sophisticated and unique Japanese culture.
sen.cmt: 文末のピリオドを一つ削除しました。
sen.e: The high aesthetics of 'netsuke' are now accepted by many people around the world as an example of sophisticated and unique Japanese culture.

sen.j: この根付の文化が現在の携帯電話などに取り付けられるストラップの伝統にもつながっていると見る説もある。
sen.e: Some people say that from this netsuke culture comes the present-day culture of using straps to attach things to mobile phones and other items.
Some people say that from this netsuke culture comes the present-day culture of using straps to attach things to mobile phones and other items.
Some people say that from this netsuke culture comes the present-day culture of using straps to attach things to mobile phones and other items.

sen.j: 根付の分類は、形状と作成地域による2種類が多く用いられる。
sen.e: Two kinds of classification are usually used for netsuke: shape and place of production.
Two kinds of classification are usually used for netsuke: shape and place of production.
Two kinds of classification are usually used for netsuke: shape and place of production.

sen.j: 形状として、輪車（環状）根付・差根付（さしねつけ）・饅頭根付・箱根付・形彫根付・柳左根付・鏡蓋根付などがある。
sen.e: For shape, there are 輪車(環状)根付, Sashi netsuke (long, slender netsuke carved in three dimensions or with relief carving), Manju netsuke (round, flat netsuke), Hako netsuke (box-type netsuke), Katabori netsuke (figural, three-dimensional sculpture), Ryusa netsuke (manju-shaped netsuke with openwork design), Kagamibuta netsuke (mirror-lid netsuke), etc.
sen.cmt: 輪車（環状）根付：読み、定訳不明。各根付の英文説明の参照元：http://www.osipovnetsuke.com/about_nets.html
sen.e: For shape, there are 輪車(環状)根付, Sashi netsuke (long, slender netsuke carved in three dimensions or with relief carving), Manju netsuke (round, flat netsuke), Hako netsuke (box-type netsuke), Katabori netsuke (figural, three-dimensional sculpture), Ryusa netsuke (manju-shaped netsuke with openwork design), Kagamibuta netsuke (mirror-lid netsuke), etc.

For shape, there are 輪車(環状)根付, Sashi netsuke (long, slender netsuke carved in three dimensions or with relief carving), Manju netsuke (round, flat netsuke), Hako netsuke (box-type netsuke), Katabori netsuke (figural, three-dimensional sculpture), Ryusa netsuke (manju-shaped netsuke with openwork design), Kagamibuta netsuke (mirror-lid netsuke), etc.

sen.j: 作成地域は江戸、京都、中京（名古屋市・伊勢国・岐阜県）、石見国が有名である。
sen.e: As for places of production, Edo, Kyoto, Chukyo (Nagoya City, Ise Province, Gifu Prefecture) and Iwami Province are well-known.
As for places of production, Edo, Kyoto, Chukyo (Nagoya City, Ise Province, Gifu Prefecture) and Iwami Province are well-known.
